titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Peter F. Geithner papers FA1408

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-01 01:05:35 -0400.

did.unittitle: Peter F. Geithner papers

physdesc.extent: 123 LTR size Hollinger boxes, 3 Half-LTR size Hollinger boxes, and 18 LGL size Hollinger boxes

did.langmaterial:
Materials are predominately in English. However, due to the nature of Peter F. Geithner's work in Asia, Africa, and other locations outside of the United States, there are documents in various other languages found throughout the collection. These languages include Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Thai, Korean, and Hindi among others. The items in the collection that are written in these languages generally consist of conference publications and papers, promotional material for organizations in different foreign countries, and travel brochures and maps. Oftentimes, these items include translations in one or more other languages, and English is usually one of the languages.
Travel brochures and other types of travel guide material are not described. Most other types of documents partially written or completely written in a language other than English are noted at the file level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection holds the papers of Peter F. Geithner who served as Regional Director of Asia Programs for the Ford Foundation between 1990 and 1996. It contains both professional and personal material, and although it chiefly consists of records created during the course of Geithner's long career in philanthropy, it was maintained by Geithner as an individual person and stored at his home in Orleans, Massachusetts. See the Other Finding Aids note to locate Ford Foundation records created by Geithner during his time as Regional Director of Asia Programs.

The collection consists of six series and seven subseries that correspond to the different organizational systems Geithner employed to arrange his papers. Although the creation dates extend from 1951 when Geithner was a student at Dartmouth College to 2011, the bulk of the collection originates from Geithner's time as Ford's Regional Director of Asia Programs as well as from the period following his retirement from Ford in 1996. Furthermore, there is far more professional material than personal material in the collection. It should be noted that a significant amount of the collection's content was impacted by mold growth and removed for remediation treatment. Files with earlier creation dates and files containing personal material were among those contaminated with mold.

The majority of the collection's material is encompassed by the first two series. These series are based on the two main arrangement schemes Geithner used to organize his records. Documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled alphabetically, A-Z comprise Series 1, and documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled numerically, 1-14D comprise Series 2. The broad scopes of these two series are represented within the titles created for them during processing. These titles are Series 1. Professional and personal files, first run and Series 2. Professional and personal files, second run. Although the later four series in the collection have more clearly defined focuses and/or internal arrangements, more substantial amounts of records on most of the topics, individuals, and organizations represented within those series are likely to be found in Series 1 and 2.

Files that document Geithner's professional activities mostly originate from four sources: 1) His career at Ford; 2) His advisor positions at the Harvard University Asia Center and the Japan Foundation Center for Global Partnership (CGP); 3) His consultancy appointments with Ford, the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB); and 4) His board and committee memberships with organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI). Through his work with these organizations and his other professional contacts, he often collaborated with, served, or came into contact with a number of other civil society, research, and international cooperation groups. Some of these organizations include the Japan Center for International Cooperation (JCIE), the Commission on Human Security (CHS), the Asia Society, the Asia Foundation, the Aspen Institute, the Harvard University Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation, the Council on Foundations, the American Indian Foundation (AIF), the City University of New York (CUNY) Center for Philanthropy and Civil Society, and the Asia Development Research Forum (ADRF).

Personal materials within the collection chiefly consist of Geithner's correspondence with family members and friends as well as a few photographs. Some celebrations and family vacation plans are documented within the files containing personal items.

The most prevalent material formats found in the collection are correspondence, reports, drafts, notes, memos, conference proceedings, agendas, schedules, pamphlets, invoices and receipts, newspaper clippings, cards, maps, and publications. Geithner also created specific files to document his business trips, and they all include copies of the travel reports he would write to log his activities. Additionally, there are several photographs and digital media items in the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

acqinfo.p: Donated to the Rockefeller Archive Center by Peter F. Geithner in 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into six series and seven subseries.

The six series derive from the original systems of arrangement used to organize the collection that were discerned during acquisition, accessioning, and processing. Peter F. Geithner appears to have used several different systems and methods for organizing his personal papers. His movements between different offices and different homes and the large timespan from which the records originate may help illuminate why the papers have various arrangement schemes. Furthermore, a significant amount of material was impacted by mold growth and removed from the collection pending mold remediation. Greater insight into Geithner's organizational systems may be gained if the impacted material is treated and reintegrated into the collection.

The bulk of the collection's content is contained within the first two groupings of material observed within the collection. The first grouping housed the content in a set of boxes labeled alphabetically, A-Z, while the second housed the content in a set of boxes labeled numerically, 1-14D. In regards to the A-Z boxes, the alphabetical arrangement did not reflect the organization of the files within those containers. The 1-14D boxes also did not have a consistent internal organizational structure for the files it held. Both groupings contained records created during Geithner's time at the Ford Foundation as well as from after he retired from Ford. They also both contain professional and personal material, and they overlap in terms of creation dates. Within the finding aid, they are described as Series 1 and 2. Professional and personal files, first and second run.

The other four groupings are smaller and have more clearly defined points of focus. Original box titles, internal arrangement schemes, and varying points of origin helped identify these groupings. They are described in the finding aid as: Series 3. Ford Foundation, Vietnam and China; Series 4. Ford Foundation, Asia-Pacific regional issues; Series 5. Professional and personal files, third run; and Series 6. Ford Foundation, trips, meetings, and conferences. Series 3 was broken into two subseries during processing in order to represent its different topical groupings and Series 5 was broken into five subseries during processing in order to represent its different topical groupings and internal organizational systems.

Original order was maintained as much as possible. Records were only moved in the few instances where reordering would support the original arrangement schemes implemented by Geithner. For instance, an original box of materials titled 14C was moved into the second series in order to maintain the numerical system of arrangement Geithner used for that segment of his materials. Likewise, another box of materials was relocated within the collection in order to reconstitute the subject files grouping found in Series 5.

Although Geithner had created files for the majority of the documents found within the collection, there was a significant amount of loose materials in the original boxes. Files were created during processing in order to organize and properly house those records. Decisions regarding these files were based off of structural indications – uses of rubber bands or binder clips to group together items – as well as by contextual and content-centered relationships between items.
The collection arrangement is as follows:
Series 1. Professional and personal files, first run, 1963-2004
Series 2. Professional and personal files, second run, 1951-2011
Series 3. Ford Foundation, Vietnam and China, 1973-1996
Series 3 Subseries 1. Ford Foundation, Vietnam, 1973-1996
Series 3 Subseries 2. Ford Foundation, China, 1986-1996
Series 4. Ford Foundation, Asia-Pacific regional issues, 1994-1999
Series 5. Professional and personal files, third run, 1982-2005
Series 5. Subseries 1. Philanthropy, 1994-2005
Series 5. Subseries 2. Subject files, 1982-2005
Series 5. Subseries 3. Correspondence with individuals, 1995-2005
Series 5. Subseries 4. Philanthropic organizations and research institutions, 1995-2004
Series 5. Subseries 5. Reports, articles, and publications, 1983-2004
Series 6. Ford Foundation, trips, meetings, and conferences, 1989-1997

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Peter Franz Geithner (1932-2016) worked in the field of international philanthropy for more than 40 years. Between 1968 and 1996, he provided leadership for the Ford Foundation's program activities in Asia, becoming Ford's Regional Director of Asia Programs in 1990. After serving at Ford for almost three decades, he retired from the foundation in 1996, but remained active in philanthropic organizations and research institutions for many years after that through advisory positions, consultancy appointments, and memberships on various boards and committees. Geithner was married to Deborah Moore, and together, they had four children: Timothy, Sarah, Jonathan, and David.

Raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Geithner attended Northeast High School. He graduated in 1950 and then pursued his undergraduate education at Dartmouth College. Between 1954 and 1958, he served in the U.S. Navy as a naval aviator, and he earned his master's degree from the John Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies in 1959. Prior to his work at the Ford Foundation, Geithner had jobs at Columbia Carbon International in New York City between 1959 and 1962 and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Washington D.C. between 1962 and 1968.

Geithner began his career at Ford in 1968 as Assistant/Deputy Director for India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. The Geithner family moved to New Delhi, India in order for him to take up the post. He held this position until 1973 when he and his family relocated to New York where he became Deputy Head, Office of Asia and Pacific. In 1976, he returned to Asia in order to serve as Ford's Representative for Southeast Asia at the Bangkok, Thailand Office. This position preceded a move back to New York in 1981 when he worked as Program Officer in Charge, Developing Countries Program. He became Ford's first representative for China in 1988 and was stationed at the foundation's new Beijing Office. He finished his career at Ford in New York as Regional Director of Asia Programs.

Following his retirement from the Ford Foundation in 1996, Geithner became Advisor to the Asia Center at Harvard University. He also worked as an advisor for the Japan Center for Global Partnership (CGP) and had a succession of consulting appointments with the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), Ford, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB). In addition, he served on boards and committees for organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI).

Geithner continued to focus on philanthropy and research related to Asia in his post-Ford career. However, he also participated in some philanthropic work related to Africa such as when he assisted the Rockefeller Foundation's Nairobi, Kenya Office.

Geithner's work in philanthropy, international relations, and development intersected with and influenced many important historical events and movements affecting the Asia-Pacific Region such as the strengthening of diplomatic ties between the United States and countries like China and Vietnam, the international response to China following the June Fourth Incident at Tiananmen Square, China's economic development and growing place in world politics, the transfer of Hong Kong back to China, the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, and the impact of terrorism and the War on Terror on philanthropy and international cooperation.

Envelope from U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission in India Galen L. Stone
did.physdesc:
File contains a still image addressed to Peter F. Geithner and his wife Deborah from U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission Galen L. Stone. The individuals depicted within include Peter and Deborah Geithner as well as their four children, Timothy, Sarah, Jonathan, and David.
The photograph was taken by R. N. Khanna in New Delhi, India. It is undated, but because the envelope in which it was sealed was addressed to the Geithners' address in New Delhi, it is likely that it was taken at some point during Peter F. Geithner's time as Ford Foundation Deputy Representative for India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka (1968-1973).

Professional and personal files, second run

physdesc.extent: About 40 LTR size Hollinger boxes and 6 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the segment of Peter F. Geithner's professional and personal files that was originally organized in boxes labeled 1-14D.
Personal correspondence at the end of the series chiefly consists of letters and notes written to Geithner by his wife and children when he was abroad with the Ford Foundation in the mid-1970s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Within the original grouping of material, a clear distinction between records regarding Ford Foundation activities in Vietnam and records regarding Ford Foundation activities in China was observed. This distinction became the basis for the two subseries imposed during processing.
The series arrangement is as follows:
Series 3 Subseries 1. Ford Foundation, Vietnam, 1973-1996
Series 3 Subseries 2. Ford Foundation, China, 1986-1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of a group of records that was originally housed in a set of boxes titled Vietnam and China. These records were all created when Peter F. Geithner worked as the Ford Foundation's Representative for China in Beijing between 1988 and 1990 and when he worked as Ford's Regional Director of Asia Program in New York City between 1990 and 1996. They regard Ford's activities in Vietnam and China in a time period spanning from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s. The series encompasses two subseries. One holds the Vietnam related files and the other holds the China related files.
The series contains many press and publication items that Geithner received or collected in relation to Vietnam and China. This is particularly true of Series 3 Subseries 2.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation, Vietnam

physdesc.extent: About 1.75 LTR size Hollinger boxes and 2 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries documents the Ford Foundation's activities in Vietnam during the time that Peter F. Geithner served as Regional Director of Asia Programs (1990-1996). Most of the records were created through the Foundation's efforts to further develop the Vietnam Program run out of the Bangkok, Thailand Regional Office as well as to open a new Regional Office in Hanoi, Vietnam.

A significant portion of the subseries consists of loosely organized reports, articles, and guides regarding an assortment of Vietnam-related topics. These subjects include economic and social development, strengthening of diplomatic relations with the U.S. and international relations with other foreign countries, and human rights.

Ford Foundation, China

physdesc.extent: About 1.25 LTR size Hollinger boxes and 4 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries documents Peter F. Geithner's engagement with various China-related issues during the periods he served as Ford Foundation Representative for China (1988-1990) and Regional Director for Asia Programs (1990-1996). Most of the material consists of newspaper clippings, journal articles, reports, and conference papers, amongst an array of other types of publications and press. These records discuss such topics as economic and political reforms in China, China's international relations and foreign policy (mostly focused on U.S.-China relations), environmental issues and sustainable development, agricultural development, legal system reform, pro-democracy movements, and government repression of intellectuals and political dissidents. Media coverage and academic analysis of the student-led protests at Tiananmen Square and the June Fourth Incident are featured prominently within the subseries as are the coverage and analysis of the international response to the events and China's subsequent economic and political trajectory. A few pieces of correspondence from Geithner help to relay his perspective on the incidents. He wrote the letters in May 1989 to family members as well as to the Ford Office in Dhaka, Bangladesh, just days before the violence occurred.

Although the subseries does not include many documents that reveal the Ford Foundation's specific program activities in China during the times that Geithner was China Representative or Regional Director for Asia Programs, Geithner's accumulation of these articles and reports suggests that he used these sources to inform his outlook on numerous issues affecting China as well as his program decisions for Ford's activities in the country. There are notes that indicate he requested the material as well as notes that show he received it from colleagues and personal relations who believed that he would be interested in the content. Moreover, Geithner added notes and annotations to many of the papers and articles. A significant portion of the reports are actually drafts that authors submitted to Geithner for his review.

physdesc.extent: 2 LTR size Hollinger boxes and 2 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of a group of Peter F. Geithner's professional files that was originally stored in a set of boxes titled Ford Foundation files and diaries. During collection accessioning, mold was discovered on most of the content within those boxes. This prompted archivists to remove all contaminated documents from the collection for mold remediation treatment. Consequently, the amount of content was reduced to less than half of its original size. Significant contextual information that may provide insight into why Geithner grouped these records in this way is therefore unavailable for the time being.

Such information could clarify Geithner's use of the title, Ford Foundation Files, 8/95-8/97, for the two boxes of material that could be processed and opened to public use. The combination of the title and date may seem confusing when considering that Geithner retired from Ford in 1996. Moreover, some of the content within the boxes originates from as late as 1999, several years after Geithner's retirement. It was decided during processing to keep the records as part of their own series and to retain the Ford Foundation title in order to represent Geithner's original system of arrangement that, due to the removed material, could not be fully understood. The series description was simply expanded to better represent the content of the records.

Records within the series document Geithner's engagement with issues involving the Asia-Pacific region in the mid and late 1990s such as the transfer of Hong Kong back to China and the 1997 Asian financial crisis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Several different organizational schemes and content groupings were identified for the collection material originally stored in a run of untitled boxes. They became the basis for the five subseries imposed during processing.
The series arrangement is as follows:
Series 5. Subseries 1. Philanthropy, 1994-2005
Series 5. Subseries 2. Subject files, 1982-2005
Series 5. Subseries 3. Correspondence with individuals, 1995-2005
Series 5. Subseries 4. Philanthropic organizations and research institutions, 1995-2004
Series 5. Subseries 5. Reports, articles, and publications, 1983-2004

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of a group of records that was originally stored in an untitled set of boxes. Like Series 1 and 2, it contains both professional and personal material.

Peter F. Geithner appears to have imposed consistent content-related groupings and arrangement schemes to organize the documents. These distinct segments are described as five individual subseries in the finding aid. The first subseries contains files regarding the field of international and region-specific philanthropy. Subseries 2 consists of a group of subject files, and Subseries 3 consists of a group of correspondence files. Records regarding Geithner's work with individual foundations and research institutions can be found in Subseries 4, and finally, Subseries 5 contains an assortment of various reports, articles, and publications.
Most of the content within the series originates from between 1996 and 2004. This is a period that followed right after Geithner retired from the Ford Foundation.

did.unittitle: Philanthropy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries documents Peter F. Geithner's involvement in efforts by the field of international and region-specific philanthropy to discuss, analyze, and improve non-profit programming, management, and strategy rather than his work with specific philanthropic projects, devised and managed by foundations and other civil society organizations. It contains reports, articles, and directories that describe non-profit organizations, trends, and issues during the time in which the records were created. Furthermore, it holds files that Geithner created to document his participation in philanthropy-related meetings, workshops, and conferences.

Correspondence, reports, and other types of records within the subseries reveal that during this time period, individuals and organizations involved in civil society contemplated such subjects as corporate social responsibility, funds management, and non-profit organization self-regulation and transparency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains a group of records organized by the first letter of the document's subject. An individual file was created for each letter or group of letters from the alphabet. Files are arranged in alphabetical order, but subjects within a file are not ordered alphabetically. Subjects were determined by the records' creator, and they include names of topics, organizations, and individuals. File level scope and content notes have been added in order to provide researchers better insight into the contents of individual subject files.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with individuals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains a group of records organized by the names of individual correspondents with whom Peter F. Geithner communicated. Files were created for each correspondent or set of correspondents. However, files are not alphabetically arranged by the last name of the correspondent(s). Both professional and personal correspondence can be found within the subseries.

Files contains material that was not produced or received by the correspondent identified in the file title. Instead, the identified correspondent was featured as the subject within correspondence between Geithner and another individual. In the case of the Phetkanha, Yui, 1998-1999 file (Folder 1712), the file only includes correspondence that references the identified correspondent and contains no correspondence created or received by Phetkanha.
The subseries also holds some miscellaneous reports and papers that were inserted in between the subject files. The relationship between this content and the subject files is unclear.

Philanthropic organizations and research institutions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents Peter F. Geithner's involvement with various philanthropic organizations and research institutions following his retirement from the Ford Foundation in 1996. For the majority of these organizations, Geithner worked either as an advisor or as a board/committee member. Individual files were created to hold the records of specific organizations, and they generally contain correspondence, reports, and promotional material that concern a particular project, initiative, workshop, or meeting. Records regarding the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF) show Geithner's role in advising the foundation on nonprofit management.

Researchers should search the first two series of the collection in order to discover more substantial documentation of the majority of organizations featured within the subseries. However, the subseries does contain the collection's most extensive amount of records regarding Geithner's association with the Global Policy Exchange. These records concern the organization's efforts to bring cultural perspectives to policy decisions on issues of international security, anti-terrorism measures, and the West's relationship with Muslim-majority countries. Improved understandings of Islam and Muslim communities in Indonesia are heavily discussed.

Reports, articles, and publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of reports, articles, newspapers clippings, books, newsletters, and promotional material. Peter F. Geithner may have acquired some of these publications in order to inform his or other individuals' outlook on a particular issue or topic. For instance, there is a significant amount of content regarding different China-related subjects. Other papers and publications were sent as drafts to Geithner for his review and/or revisions.

Geithner participated in the writing and compilation of a few of the publications contained within the subseries. These publications originated from projects Geithner worked on after he retired from his post at the Ford Foundation. His consultancy appointments for Ford's Beijing, China and Hanoi, Vietnam Office produced two of the reports found in the subseries. There are also a number of files that document how the diaspora philanthropy volume for the Harvard University Global Equity Initiative (GEI) Diaspora Philanthropy Workshop (DPW) was put together and revised.
In addition to various kinds of press and publications, the subseries includes a photograph of the Ford Foundation's New Delhi, India Office staff in 1985.

Ford Foundation, trips, meetings, and conferences

physdesc.extent: 3 LTR size Hollinger boxes and 1 Half-LTR size Hollinger box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists entirely of files Peter F. Geithner created to document business trips, meetings, and conferences during his last few years as Ford Foundation Regional Director of Asia Programs. The records were discovered in a filing cabinet. This distinct method of organization motivated the creation of a separate series to describe and house the materials during processing. Other materials were likely kept within this filing cabinet that could potentially provide more contextual information for the documents and this system of arrangement; however, those materials were impacted by mold growth and have been removed from the collection pending mold remediation.

Files are mainly comprised of schedules, brochures, maps, invitation and attendee lists, correspondence, memos, notes, and travel reports. As mentioned in the Collection Scope and Contents note, Geithner would write travel reports to log his activities on business trips and would insert copies of them into the files he created to document particular trips.

References to Geithner's approaching retirement from the Ford Foundation can be found within some of the materials. For example, there is an invitation to a farewell reception for Geithner at the Beijing Office in 1996 as well as a draft of the remarks Geithner planned to make at the event. A few of the files located towards the end of the series may actually originate from after Geithner's official retirement from Ford.
